awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Resolving Nonlinearity in Thin Film Chemical Analysis: Roughening, Matrix Effects and Chemical Damage
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division. Professors Lev Gelb and Amy Walker of the University of Texas at Dallas are improving methods for interpreting surface chemical analysis data. Many methods for studying a surface or thin film involve blasting it with high-energy beams of electrons or ions. These approaches provide information about the atoms and molecules present, but also cause unwanted chemical reactions and surface roughening. This team is developing easy-to-use analysis software to account for these "nonlinear" effects. The result is that the quality of surface chemical analysis data is improved, and this advances research in fields ranging from energy, to electronics, to advanced materials, to biotechnology. Graduate and undergraduate students are trained in the critically important fields of surface characterization, data analysis, numerical methods, and high-performance computing. 

This project focuses on two types of nonlinearity in chemical imaging: quantitative modeling of matrix effects in secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) imaging of organic surfaces, and resolution of chemical damage and roughening in x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) depth profiling of complex oxides. Extraction of sample properties in the presence of these nonlinearities is addressed through physical modeling within a Bayesian framework, which is made possible through a combination of theoretical developments, modern computing power, improvements in experimental protocols, and physical understanding of the underlying phenomena. In order to promote the use and further development of advanced data analysis in chemical imaging, software developed in this project is freely distributed and promoted as a community resource, along with online exercises that illustrate its use and application. SIMS and XPS are widely used in many areas, so improving the performance of these and related techniques is a significant long-term benefit to society at large.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Lev Gelb, Amy Walker, and their students at the University of Texas at Dallas have developed methods for interpreting surface chemical analysis data. Many methods for studying a surface or thin film involve blasting it with high-energy beams of electrons or ions and observing what happens. This provides information about the atoms and molecules present in the sample, but can be difficult to interpret because of nonlinear effects such as damage and chemical reactions caused by the beams, and interactions between ejected particles. By accounting for such effects, this project improves the quality of such measurements, and will advance research in fields ranging from energy to advanced materials to biotechnology. Students participating in this work have become expert in important techniques for surface analysis that
are widely available but often difficult to interpret; they are thus well-equipped to pursue impactful careers in many areas.

Nonlinearity has been studied in two different analysis methods: secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) imaging of organic surfaces, and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) depth profiling in multilayer thin films. In SIMS, an energetic beam of ions impacts the surface, which causes the ejection of fragments of molecules from the near surface region. The masses of the fragments are then determined, which gives information about their chemical formula. The fragments observed from a given molecule depend on what other molecules are present, though, which can lead to incorrect estimates for molecular compositions and concentrations. We introduced a mathematical framework for resolving these "matrix effects," and showed that it provided improved results. In addition, we studied the resolution limits of SIMS and showed that by careful and systematic analysis ion masses could be determined to much higher precision than they usually are, which helps with identification of the molecules present.

In XPS depth profiling, an ion beam is used to gradually remove the top layers of a sample ("sputtering"), while simultaneous analysis with x-rays provides chemical information. However, the sputtering causes the surface to become rough and atoms near the surface to move around, and the x-ray analysis penetrates more deeply into the sample than one would like. We have demonstrated a new analysis approach which uses realistic simulations of the depth profiling experiment to extract a good description of the original sample structure. SIMS and XPS are widely used in many areas, so improving the performance of these and related techniques will be of significant long-term benefit to society at large.  As these methods are further refined, the analysis software will be freely distributed and promoted as a community resource, along with online exercises that illustrate its use and application.

These and related techniques have been applied in several collaborative efforts in conservation science.  Working with conservators and conservation scientists at the Edith O'Donnell Institute of Art History, the Amon Carter Museum, and the Rikjsmuseum (in the Netherlands) we have used SIMS, XPS and advanced analysis techniques to study the chemistry of glass degradation and the conservation of historical glass samples, the indentification of dyes in hundred-year-old prints by the Mexican artist Jos? Guasalupe Posada, and the discoloration and restoration of lead-based glazes in Delft ceramics.
